descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses @jamesdyke that technology is mature and broadly available. It won't do this under capitalism because this is about contributing to, rather than enclosing, the commons.

That technology is nuclear energy. Thermodynamically, you need about 394.4 kJ/mol to turn atmospheric CO₂ into graphite, so double that for various inefficiencies. From there, you can figure out how much we have to build to get back to 350. Yes, it's a lot, but it is completely doable.

account.note: Parent, geek, public speaker, ND, PIC abolitionist, nuclear energy fan.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses @jamesdyke

However "temporary overshoot" is correct on a geological scale. But this will however not help us much in the first place.

account.note:
🌏 Born at 312 PPM

Retired NGO executive doing my best to stay informed and raise awareness about environmental crises, climate breakdown, and the rapacious, murderous impact of greedy capitalists and the politicians they own.

Why the name? Back in the day, empires placated their citizens with "bread and circuses." Now we get fast food and apps. But it's all basically the same — distraction from what's REALLY happening.

fields.name: See my Toots
fields.value: https://justmytoots.com/@breadandcircuses@climatejustice.social

fields.name: Favorite saying
fields.value: "Be kind to everyone you meet, for they are fighting a great battle.”

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses Meanwhile, climate change is number 18 on US voters' list of priorities for this election. The economy is number 1 by far, which means no US politician is going to stay in office long if they do something that's perceived to harm the economy "just" to protect the environment.

Doesn't matter how loud we scream. Nobody's listening. It's going to take a massive catastrophe to wake people up. Unfortunately, catastrophes are going to be far more frequent and severe in the countries least responsible for climate change. And as people move around that brings us to one of US voters' top concerns: immigration.

It's going to take a massive climate disaster hitting a wealthy US city, like a category 5 hurricane hitting New York.

Which is not to say you're wasting your breath! Without the screaming, even such a disaster wouldn't be enough; people would just chalk it up to bad luck and move on. It's important that people keep hearing these warnings so that it does eventually dawn on them that we really need to act, and what needs to be done.

@jamesdyke

account.note: AU farmer, advocate for landscape management, concerned, affected, observing natural systems in distress with humans driving and asking are there prerequisites for people, production and systems to be resilient - “The era of procrastination, of half-measures, of soothing and baffling expedients, of delays is coming to its close.
